author: By Joseph Turow
title: Hear That? It’s Your Voice Being Taken for Profit.
description: 'When she recognizes you’re frustrated with her, Alexa can now try to adjust, just like you or I would do.'
content: If you’ve ever dialed an 800 number to ask or complain about something you bought or to make an inquiry about something you’re thinking of buying, there is a decent chance you were profiled — by the arrangement of your words and the tone of your voice — without knowing it. My research suggests many customer contact centers now approach and manage callers based on what they think the person’s voice or syntax reveal about the individual’s emotions, sentiments and personality, often in real time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: In Orban’s Hungary, Pope Urges Bishops to Embrace Diversity
description: On a quick trip to the country, Francis met with Prime Minister Viktor Orban, Hungary’s hard-right leader, before celebrating a public Mass.
content: BUDAPEST — Pope Francis used his short time in Budapest on Sunday to urge his bishops to embrace diversity and send a message to the country’s hard-right, anti-migrant leader, Prime Minister Viktor Orban, that God is not a strongman who silences enemies and that religious roots, while vital for a country, also allow it to open up and extend “its arms toward everyone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The U.S. lags on vaccines.
content: The country ranks last among the Group of 7 nations for the percentage of its population that has received at least one dose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Trump Talked as Holyfield Got Pummeled. Just Another Day in Boxing’s Absurd Summer.
description: Of course it was a circus — the kind that makes sense in boxing these days.
content: In a single zany sentence, this is how the once-promising summer of boxing ended: Triller, a social video app that is a much less popular version of TikTok, put on a pay-per-view fight between a 58-year-old Evander Holyfield (who hasn’t fought in a decade) and a 44-year-old mixed martial artist, Vitor Belfort — and paid former President Donald J. Trump and Donald Trump Jr. to serve as live commentators, all on the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: 1-Year-Old Is Killed, and Mother’s Boyfriend Is Arrested
description: The infant, Legacy Beauford, was killed in the Bronx. In Brooklyn, a 4-year-old boy died after being found unconscious in a hallway.
content: The night before 1-year-old Legacy Beauford died, he was crying uncontrollably.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: The Legacy of America’s Post-9/11 Turn to Torture
description: Twenty years after the attacks, the United States is still grappling with the consequences of brutal interrogations carried out in the name of national security.
content: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania — Mohamedou Ould Slahi is almost clinical as he recalls details of the torture he endured in the summer of 2003 at Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Giulia Heyward
title: Vaccination ‘should be a personal health care choice’: Republican governors argue against Biden’s new plan.
description: The officials portrayed the vaccine mandates as violations of civil liberties.
content: Republicans officials on Sunday made further threats of legal action against President Biden’s sweeping plan to get tens of millions of American workers vaccinated, with even those who openly urge that people get shots claiming that the mandate violated civil liberties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: George Soros Is Making Changes at His Foundation While He Still Can
description: The result is a painful restructuring to focus on the fight against rising authoritarianism around the world.
content: The mass email that went out to Open Society Foundations’ grant recipients in the United States in March began with an upbeat note about “how resistance is translating into real progress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: ‘We Didn’t Have a Plan’: Disabled People Struggle to Evacuate From Wildfires
description: In Northern California, a region troubled by fire, many people with disabilities live in rural areas that lack the resources to support them during disasters.
content: A mandatory evacuation notice blared from Joyce Lindahl’s phone one day in July as the Dixie fire bore down on her home in Northern California. But her biggest concern was an hour away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany’s Election Was His to Lose, and He Might Just Do That
description: Armin Laschet, Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union party’s candidate for chancellor, is flagging in the polls, and he seems to be dragging the party down with him.
content: FRANKFURT AN DER ODER, Germany — His party is the biggest in Germany. It has won all but three elections since 1950, including the past four. Its departing chancellor is more popular than any politician in the country. And German voters crave stability and continuity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wolpe
title: So You’ve Been Canceled: A Yom Kippur Atonement Guide
description: A rabbi's advice for those who have done wrong and those who can’t forgive.
content: A friend of mine was publicly canceled. He deserved it and he knew it. He spent a year working with a rabbi and a therapist, during which time he tried to track down those he had hurt and apologize to them, often more than once. We can’t see inside one another’s hearts, but I believe in the sincerity of his change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Lemire
title: Emotions High as Subway Series Coincides With 9/11 Anniversary
description: In a season of highs and lows for the Yankees and the Mets, the teams split the first two games of a series. But they joined each other in a moment of unity on Saturday.
content: Within the past month, the Yankees managed to win 13 straight games but also endure losing streaks of four and seven games. The Mets began August in first place and ended it in third place, out of the playoff picture and apologetic that some of their stars had been flashing thumbs-down gestures to their own fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: 9/11, Vaccine mandates, California recall: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 12, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 12, 2021.
content: An article this weekend on Page 13 about Kelly Clarkson misstates which Coldplay song her children were brought out to hear Chris Martin perform. It was “Yellow,” not “Green Eyes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Saquon Barkley is in. Here’s who’s out.
description: Coming into Week 1, most teams’ optimism hinges on the health of their rosters. A few star players whose status had been murky this week, including Giants running back Saquon Barkley, Chargers running back Austin Ekeler, and Colts guard Quenton Nelson, are good to go.
content: Coming into Week 1, most teams’ optimism hinges on the health of their rosters. A few star players whose status had been murky this week, including Giants running back Saquon Barkley, Chargers running back Austin Ekeler, and Colts guard Quenton Nelson, are good to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In Social Policy Bill, Businesses See a Lot to Like. They Oppose It.
description: Resistance to tax increases outweighs the appeal of a $3.5 trillion measure containing child care credits and other items that corporations embrace.
content: WASHINGTON — The far-reaching social policy bill under construction in Congress has much that corporate America has long sought from Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Fashion in the Shadow of 9/11
description: Thom Browne, Rachel Comey and Rodarte put some drama back in dress.
content: A ghostly mansion inside The Shed: Boxwood hedges and desiccated urns filled an ersatz formal garden constructed in the performance space of Hudson Yards, the elaborate real estate development built on the Far West Side of Manhattan just before Covid-19 hit and which has stood as something of an empty monument to prepandemic dreams of grandeur and greed for the last two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and Photographs By Todd Heisler
title: ‘Black Capitalism’ Promised a Better City for Everyone. What Happened?
description: In the wake of nationwide protests, corporate America has pledged to fight racism and support Black Americans. But a similar initiative started decades ago in Rochester shows it is a promise that is difficult to sustain.
content: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — The Panther Graphics printing plant sits along a row of red brick buildings and empty parking lots on the edge of a circular highway that separates this city’s downtown from a largely Black neighborhood to the north. Nearby, there is a warehouse, a Baptist Church and a billboard that warns “A Shot from A Gun Can’t Be Undone,” a reference to Rochester’s soaring murder rate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Joffe and Jody Steinauer
title: Even Texas Allows Abortions to Protect a Woman’s Life. Or Does It?
description: History shows us that what counts as a threat to a womans life isn't always clear-cut.
content: Join us, if you will, in a thought experiment. It’s the fall of 2022. Dr. H., an obstetrician-gynecologist, practices in a red state. Much has changed in the reproductive rights landscape by then: In the spring, her state rushed to pass a law similar to the notorious 2021 Texas law that bans a large majority of abortions and incentivizes private citizens to sue anyone helping someone get an abortion. The Supreme Court also overturned Roe v. Wade in the Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization case that year, leaving the issue of abortion regulation to individual states; a few years before, Dr. H.’s state passed a trigger ban that automatically banned the few abortions that were still legal in the state when Roe fell. In her state, the law now allows an abortion only when a pregnancy threatens the life of a pregnant person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: What Should You Do with Your Covid Fatigue?
description: The Bible shows us what it means to persevere.
content: After we got our second Covid-19 vaccinations last April, my husband and I went to dinner inside a restaurant for the first time in over a year. We toasted to the new day ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: West Virginia, once a vaccination pacesetter, is struggling against the Delta variant.
description: The state now has the country’s lowest percentage of vaccinated residents 18 and over, despite efforts from state officials to reach the hesitant.
content: Coronavirus cases are nearing record levels  in West Virginia, and the state’s schools are closing and its hospitals are choked with patients stricken by the perniciously infectious Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Mick Tingelhoff, Vikings Hall of Fame Center, Dies at 81
description: He started in 240 consecutive games and played in four Super Bowls, providing pass protection for quarterback Fran Tarkenton.
content: Mick Tingelhoff, the Hall of Fame center who started in 240 consecutive games in his 17 seasons with the Minnesota Vikings and who played in four Super Bowls, died on Saturday at an assisted living facility in Lakeville, Minn. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Nicholas to Bring Heavy Rain to Texas and Louisiana
description: The storm could produce up to 16 inches of rain in parts of coastal Texas through the middle of the week, the National Hurricane Center said.
content: Tropical Storm Nicholas, which formed on Sunday in the Gulf of Mexico, could bring heavy rains to coastal Texas and Louisiana on Monday and Tuesday as it strengthens, the National Hurricane Center said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: As Novak Djokovic Faces History, He Tries to Block It Out
description: To capture the first Grand Slam in men’s tennis in 52 years, Djokovic must beat Daniil Medvedev in the U.S. Open final. “Mentally, he’s the best player to ever play the game,” Djokovic’s semifinal opponent said.
content: Follow our live coverage of the U.S. Open men’s singles championship match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: The surgeon general insists the government ‘has the legal authority’ to enforce Biden’s vaccine mandates.
description: Dr. Viveck Murthy acknowledged the unhappiness the coronavirus had engendered, but added: “What we cannot allow is for this pandemic to turn us on each other. Our enemy is the virus. It is not one another.”
content: Dr. Vivek Murthy, the surgeon general, made the rounds on  Sunday television shows to defend the Biden administration’s new Covid vaccine mandates, portraying them as  narrow directives that apply only to specific professions where the federal government “has legal authority to act” — a direct counter to Republican accusations of unconstitutional federal overreach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Joseph Brodsky Slept Here. The Great Poet’s Cranky Neighbor Couldn’t Care Less.
description: After a decades-long standoff with the last resident of a communal apartment, a private museum has finally opened in Brodsky’s shared home in St. Petersburg, a rare grass-roots victory in Russia.
content: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Until he fled the Soviet Union in 1972, the Russian poet Joseph Brodsky lived in a drab communal apartment in St. Petersburg, sharing a bathroom and kitchen with three other families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: Two Parents Are the First to Face Trial in College Admissions Scandal
description: At issue are the parents’ conduct, U.S.C.’s admissions practices and possibly the fairness of the college admissions process itself.
content: Gamal Abdelaziz, a former hotel and casino executive, is accused of paying $300,000 to get his daughter admitted to the University of Southern California as a basketball player based on false qualifications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: If the Police Lie, Should They Be Held Liable? Often the Answer Is No.
description: Federal agents and police officers who work with them are often immune from lawsuits, even for serious rights violations. The Supreme Court is being asked to re-evaluate that.
content: In 2010, Officer Heather Weyker of the St. Paul Police Department in Minnesota had the biggest case of her career: a child sex-trafficking ring said to have spanned four states and involved girls as young as 12. Thirty people, almost all of them Somali refugees, were charged and sent to jail, many of them for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Medvedev takes the first set, 6-4.
description: Djokovic also lost the first set in his previous four matches, and came back to win each time.
content: Novak Djokovic finds himself in familiar territory 36 minutes into the final: down a set at the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Luchette
title: The Nuns of Fiction: Experts in Affliction and Awe
description: From Chaucer to Don DeLillo and Lauren Groff, nuns in literature have served a variety of functions — not least, Claire Luchette writes, as the authors’ stays against mortal agony.
content: A group of crows is a murder; pandas, an embarrassment; nuns, a superfluity — a term that dates to the Middle Ages, when nunneries were overcrowded, lice-ridden and destitute. Today, there’s no such thing as too many nuns, as few women are taking vows. But the nuns who are among us remain ecclesiastical workhorses. Ordained men can stand in persona Christi, allowing them, for example, the superpower of transubstantiation. But if priests stand at the front of the church as middlemen between God and the faithful, nuns are at the front lines of suffering: They bring God to the meek, poor, sick, imprisoned — those, in other words, whom society has deemed superfluous and disposable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: For 9/11 Tribute, the Met Opera Returns Home
description: The company’s first performance inside its theater since March 2020 was an inspired rendition of Verdi’s Requiem.
content: What it meant to be in the audience at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday evening — for the first indoor performance there since March 2020 — was clear even before the music began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Zach Wilson Debuts for the Jets, but His Predecessor Shines Brighter
description: Carolina’s Sam Darnold threw for 279 yards and a touchdown. Wilson threw two scoring passes but threw an interception and took six sacks while often facing heavy pressure.
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Sam Darnold threw for 279 yards and a touchdown and ran for another score against his former team as the Carolina Panthers defeated the Jets, 19-14, on Sunday to win a season opener for the first time since 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Careful!
description: A. Tariq’s debut is bunches of fun.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to A. Tariq on this lovely New York Times Crossword debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Amid cries of tyranny, Britain cancels any plan to require vaccine passports.
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson is expected to discuss the decision on Tuesday, and also to address the likelihood of Covid booster shots soon amid “renewed challenges” to come this winter.
content: After months of cries of tyranny and discrimination raised by speculation that Britain would require vaccine passports for entry into crowded venues like stores and nightclubs, the authorities said on Sunday any such plans had been scrapped, at least for the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: A Deep Dive Into Matisse’s ‘The Red Studio’
description: In a coming exhibition, MoMA will feature the  artworks within this famed painting. Two of them will be on public view for the first time in 50 years.
content: When Henri Matisse painted “The Red Studio” in the Paris suburb of Issy-les-Moulineaux in 1911, he not only let the viewer into his work space, with its box of crayons, ceramic plate and grandfather clock. He also captured tiny versions of his own paintings propped against the walls, and his sculptures perched on stools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Behind the Texas Abortion Law, a Persevering Conservative Lawyer
description: Jonathan Mitchell has never had a high profile in the anti-abortion movement, but he developed and promoted the legal approach that has flummoxed the courts and enraged abortion rights supporters.
content: Jonathan F. Mitchell grew increasingly dismayed as he read the Supreme Court’s decision in June 2016 striking down major portions of a Texas anti-abortion bill he had helped write.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Writing for the Poor
description: A paper's columnists should be like an orchestra, each playing a different instrument. I decided that  I was going to play the banjo.
content: One of my favorite aunts was desperately poor, like many people I knew in rural north Louisiana. I don’t know how much money she had or made. I only know the shadow of need that stalked her. She seemed, like many members of my family, one paycheck or severe injury away from insolvency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Join Us for a Conversation on Greening Cryptocurrency
description: On Oct. 5, Andrew Ross Sorkin and the DealBook team explore the environmental impact of digital currency and efforts to make it more sustainable.
content: As corporations increasingly emphasize environmental and sustainability goals, where exactly does energy-intensive cryptocurrency fit in? How do the opportunities surrounding crypto compare with the resources it consumes? And how do we make the mining process more sustainable?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: G.O.P. Seethes at Biden Mandate, Even in States Requiring Other Vaccines
description: Resistance to vaccine mandates, once a fringe position, has entered the Republican mainstream. But the governors fighting President Biden’s Covid-19 requirements impose mandates of their own.
content: WASHINGTON — Like other Republican governors around the country, Tate Reeves of Mississippi reacted angrily to the coronavirus vaccine mandates President Biden imposed on private businesses. Declaring the move “terrifying,” he wrote on Twitter: “This is still America, and we still believe in freedom from tyrants.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Ready, Set, Don’t Get Injured
description: Marathon season is upon us for the first time since 2019. But, a doctor warns, “Your body right now is not the same body you had two years ago, so you’ve got to pay attention to that.”
content: The pattern is a familiar one for sports medicine doctors, orthopedic surgeons and physical therapists. Marathon season — usually a stretch lasting from mid-August to December — means more patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Simon
title: The Question Michael K. Williams Asked Me Before Every Season of ‘The Wire’
description: As Omar Little, the actor bent his beautiful mind to a task that even the best writers and showrunners often avoid.
content: The second season of our fledgling HBO drama in Baltimore did not shoot its first frame of film before one key cast member was in the writers’ offices, scripts in hand, showing his disappointment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: After the 9/11 Attacks, Boston Found a Focus for Its Anger
description: Terrorists boarded two planes in Boston and flew them into the World Trade Center. Massachusetts zeroed in on its top airport official, who has never quite recovered.
content: BOSTON — Virginia Buckingham remembers the moment when she realized that she had been singled out. She had stopped at Dunkin’ Donuts on her way into Logan International Airport, which she oversaw as the top official at the Massachusetts Port Authority. As she stood in line, a man behind her whispered to his friend, “That’s her.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: The Saints chose Jacksonville because of its inaccessibility to Packers fans.
description: New Orleans will play its home opener in Florida after Hurricane Ida’s destruction displaced the team.
content: No, it’s not a misprint. Yes, the end zones at TIAA Bank Stadium, home of the Jacksonville Jaguars, really do say “SAINTS.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Isabella Kwai
title: A New Sports Star Showcases the Diversity of a More Complex Britain
description: Emma Raducanu, 18, galvanized the nation with her triumph in the U.S. Open, drawing congratulations from royalty and inspiring pride in her hometown outside London.
content: LONDON — At long last, Britain got the outpouring of national jubilation it has craved this summer, not from a men’s soccer team that narrowly missed sports immortality but from a young woman with a radiant smile, Emma Raducanu, who stormed from obscurity to win the U.S. Open tennis title on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: When Sadness Is Transformative and Grief Gets Complicated
description: Azareen Van der Vliet Oloomi talks about her new novel, “Savage Tongues,” in which two friends help each other deal with personal and political traumas.
content: At the start of “Savage Tongues,” Azareen Van der Vliet Oloomi’s third novel, the Iranian American narrator, Arezu, is arriving in Marbella, Spain. It’s her first time back in 20 years, since she was 17 and met Omar, her stepmother’s nephew, who was then 40. He would become “my lover, my torturer, my confidant and enemy,” she tells us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: A Strong Push to Vaccinate
description: The government is going to require businesses with more than 100 employees to require vaccinations or weekly Covid tests.
content: The Biden administration released a blueprint for how solar energy, which contributed less than 4 percent of the country’s electricity last year, could move toward producing almost half of the country’s electricity by 2050. This is in line with what most climate scientists say is necessary to prevent the worst effects of global warming, but it would require vast upgrades to the electric grid. Though the cost of solar panels has fallen steeply over the last decade, the plan would require trillions of dollars in investments by homeowners, businesses and the government to remake an energy infrastructure built for coal, natural gas and nuclear power plants.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: At 9/11 Ceremonies, Remembering the Day We Will Never Forget
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 12, 2021.
content: “I was only 2 when it happened. But I have learned a lot about it, and now I am teaching them.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘In the Bike’s Place Was a Lock That Had Been Cut in Half’
description: On the hunt for a stolen bicycle, lingering on the Met’s steps and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Despite Covid Risks, Many Leaders Plan to Attend U.N. General Assembly
description: Unlike the annual meeting last year, conducted almost entirely virtually because of pandemic restrictions, the United Nations is expecting leaders from at least 83 countries to speak in person.
content: The cavernous General Assembly hall of the United Nations will have far fewer vacant seats. Corridors of the organization’s iconic Manhattan headquarters, eerily silent for months, will echo with more voices and footsteps. Motorcades will whisk in dozens of world leaders to deliver speeches in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Capitol Police Inquiry Into Jan. 6 Riot Recommends Disciplining Six Officers
description: None of the officers, or details about the recommended penalties, were identified. Criminal charges will not be filed against any of the officers.
content: WASHINGTON — Capitol Police investigators have recommended disciplinary action against six police officers for their actions during the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol, when Trump supporters stormed the building in an effort to stop the certification of President Biden’s victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Iran and I.A.E.A. Reach Last-Minute Deal on Nuclear Monitoring
description: The temporary agreement should keep Tehran from censure for noncompliance by the nuclear agency, a move that could have derailed already suspended nuclear talks.
content: BRUSSELS — In a last-minute deal before Iran was likely to be censured for violating its agreements with the International Atomic Energy Agency, the new government in Tehran agreed on Sunday to let the organization reset monitoring devices that help measure the progress of the country’s nuclear program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel threatens to charge scores who returned from a Ukraine pilgrimage using faked coronavirus test results.
description: Officials said that more than 1,500 cases were identified among the 17,000 travelers who flew back on Thursday and Friday, and that more than 150 had hidden positive test results and obtained falsified negative results to travel on.
content: JERUSALEM — More than 150 Israelis suspected of using fake negative coronavirus test results to board flights home after a pilgrimage to Uman, Ukraine, have been summoned for questioning by the Israeli police in accordance with a strict, new government directive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: How Raducanu and Fernandez Forged Sudden Stardom and Deep Connections
description: Viewers of the U.S. Open embraced the young finalists in women’s singles, a pair of teenagers who seemed as if they had been around forever.
content: We adapt quickly. It’s part of the human spirit, whether we are teenage tennis stars or the people who line up and take a seat to watch them in the world’s biggest tennis stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Michael S. Schmidt
title: F.B.I. Releases Newly Declassified Document Related to Sept. 11 Attacks
description: Families of the Sept. 11 victims have long pushed for a deeper investigation into any possible role the Saudi government had in the attacks, but the document offered no conclusive evidence.
content: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. released a newly declassified document late Saturday describing connections that the agency examined between the hijackers and the Saudi government in the years since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, although it contained no conclusive evidence about whether the kingdom played a role in the attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: The N.F.L. will keep playing the Black national anthem before games.
description: In Thursday night’s season opener, players stood on the field at Raymond James Stadium with their arms intertwined as Alicia Keys and the Florida A&M choir performed “Lift Every Voice and Sing” before the game’s start.
content: In Thursday night’s season opener, players stood on the field at Raymond James Stadium with their arms intertwined as Alicia Keys and the Florida A&M choir performed “Lift Every Voice and Sing” before the game’s start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: New York Fashion Week: Day 5
description: At Thom Browne, a garden written across the face.
content: There are many things to consider when turning a person into a floral shrub.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: A Fashion Show With an Unexpected Focus: Sexual Assault Survivors
description: The show, organized by Rise, was designed to upend a question often asked of survivors: ‘What were you wearing?’
content: — Amanda Nguyen, founder of the civil rights organization Rise, which hosted a fashion show at New York Fashion Week to celebrate survivors
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Kiang
title: Venice: Women’s Stories
description: Films by or about women stood out at this year’s Venice International Film Festival, though they represented only a fraction of the titles showcased.
content: There is a moment that happens every time I am lucky enough to attend the Venice International Film Festival, just before it all begins, when overloaded screening schedules still seem perfectly doable, and deadlines are distant and abstract, almost pretty, like far-off flocks of birds. Freewheeling down the Lido (the barrier island in the Venetian lagoon where the festival takes place) on a newly rented bike, the weather reliably gorgeous, the breeze warm and the tiniest bit savory with centuries of sea-salted history, I think I am more predictably, straightforwardly happy than on any other day of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: In California, there are recall attempts for everything under the sun.
description: Votes on Tuesday involve the Sonoma County district attorney and two city council members in Vernon.
content: While all eyes were on Gov. Gavin Newsom, a developer in Sonoma County was charging forward with an effort to recall the district attorney who had sued his company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 13, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Many newspaper editorial boards are backing Newsom
description: Their endorsements point out shortcomings but cite his values and experience.
content: Despite a concerted effort from conservatives to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, most newspaper editorials in the state continue to endorse him and are strongly recommending not to vote him out of office. Many publications across the state are asking readers to overlook Mr. Newsom’s shortcomings and focus on his legislative agenda and his overall leadership during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Pochoda
title: Liane Moriarty’s New Novel Is a Family Saga and a Mystery
description: In “Apples Never Fall,” the author of “Nine Perfect Strangers” and “Big Little Lies” serves readers the tale of a missing mother and tennis pro.
content: APPLES NEVER FALLBy Liane Moriarty
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Kansas City Southern Chooses Suitor in Bid for North American Rail Link
description: After the merger with Canadian Pacific, the railroad would connect Canada, the United States and Mexico.
content: Kansas City Southern said on Sunday that it had deemed an offer from Canadian Pacific superior to a bid from Canadian National, in the latest turn in a monthslong battle to become the first railroad to connect North America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: With a Win in Portland, Alex Palou Reclaims His IndyCar Lead
description: Palou overcame a pileup during the first turn that cost him his pole position advantage, and he worked his way up the field to win the Grand Prix of Portland.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Despite a multicar pileup on the opening lap that sent the pole winner Alex Palou to the back of the pack, Palou managed to cleverly work his way back into the IndyCar championship lead and place first on Sunday at the Grand Prix of Portland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Nino Castelnuovo, ‘The Umbrellas of Cherbourg’ Star, Dies at 84
description: Mr. Castelnuovo, who brought an incandescent charm to the screen, became famous during a golden age of Italian cinema. But his breakthrough role was in a French film.
content: Nino Castelnuovo, a popular Italian film and television actor who found success beyond his home country when he starred alongside Catherine Deneuve in the soaringly sentimental French New Wave musical “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg,” died on Sept. 6 in Rome. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Medvedev seizes a two-set lead.
description: Djokovic was one set away from failing in his quest to capture the men’s Grand Slam.
content: Daniil Medvedev has tightened his grip on this U.S. Open men’s final, leading Novak Djokovic 6-4, 6-4, and putting himself one set from winning his first major title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Passion Fruit Dance Company Brings the Club to the Stage
description: The up-and-coming company tried to deliver energy to an audience in Brooklyn with “Trapped,” but the last thing we need onstage is more screen time, our critic writes.
content: As they have been doing regularly since the start of the pandemic, the father-son D.J. duo known as St. James Joy got the party started right, this time at the BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn! Festival on Friday evening. Then D.J. Pfunk and the house producer Saadiq Bolden shook the newly renamed Lena Horne Bandshell, with some stronger sounds and enough bass to make even seated bodies vibrate. The atmosphere of a dance club was taken outside mostly intact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Health Care in Afghanistan Is Crumbling, Aid Groups Warn
description: After the Taliban’s takeover, international donors withdrew funds that hospitals and clinics depended on. Now a fourth wave of Covid looms.
content: The health care system in Afghanistan is teetering on the edge of collapse, endangering the lives of millions and compounding a deepening humanitarian crisis, public health experts warn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: False Election Claims in California Reveal a New Normal for G.O.P.
description: In an echo of 2020, Republicans are pushing baseless allegations of cheating in the state’s recall race even before Election Day.
content: The results of the California recall election won’t be known until Tuesday night. But some Republicans are already predicting victory for the Democrat, Gov. Gavin Newsom, for a reason that should sound familiar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: 3000 Strikeouts Later, They Still Come Easy for Scherzer
description: Max Scherzer reached the 3,000-strikeout milestone, tossing an immaculate inning and flirting with a perfect game. His first strikeout victim remembers similar dominance.
content: Chris Snyder, the Arizona Diamondbacks’ starting catcher on April 29, 2008, was known for being chatty behind the plate during games. So when his friend Jack Cassel, the Houston Astros’ starting pitcher that day, came to bat in the third inning, Snyder asked Cassel about his younger brother, Matt, the backup quarterback to Tom Brady on the New England Patriots in the N.F.L.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Daniil Medvedev wins the U.S. Open as Novak Djokovic falls short of a Grand Slam.
description: Djokovic’s defeat was the latest twist in a tournament that overflowed with stunning performances.
content: Novak Djokovic said he was going to play this match as if it were the last of his career, that he was going to pour every ounce of his heart and soul into trying to do what few thought could ever be done again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 1 of the N.F.L. Season
description: The Steelers won a reminder game over the Bills, Russell Wilson roasted the Colts, and Jalen Hurts looked unstoppable against the Falcons.
content: [What We Learned is returning for the 2021 N.F.L. season with a new writer and a new look.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: On a Difficult Day for New York, Leylah Fernandez Moves a Tennis Crowd
description: After losing the women’s final at the U.S. Open on the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Fernandez said, “I hope I can be as strong and resilient as New York has been the last 20 years.”
content: Leylah Fernandez stood on the podium, fighting back tears. She had finished an eloquent runner-up speech, looking as if all she wanted was to disappear underneath the stands of Arthur Ashe Stadium and get a hug from her family. But she prolonged her anguish for a few more minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Torrey Peters
title: Parsing American Style
description: It’s not what we wear, but how we wear it that creates a common language of fashion.
content: It’s not what we wear, but how we wear it that creates a common language of fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Video Music Awards 2021: See All of the Red Carpet Looks
description: See Lil Nas X, Kacey Musgraves, Shawn Mendes and more stars on the red carpet.
content: See Lil Nas X, Kacey Musgraves, Shawn Mendes and more stars on the red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Hurricane Larry Makes Landfall in Newfoundland
description: Larry made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane in Newfoundland, Canada on Friday night, causing widespread power outages in the province. The storm then moved toward Greenland, where it was expected to transition into a winter storm.
content: Larry made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane in Newfoundland, Canada on Friday night, causing widespread power outages in the province. The storm then moved toward Greenland, where it was expected to transition into a winter storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Get inspired by our newest recipes, including tortilla pizzas and blackened fish with quick grits.
content: Good morning. I like the looks of Melissa Clark’s new recipe for roasted lemony fish with crispy caper brown butter and nori (above) and might make it tonight if I can find good fish at the market. But I’ll tell you this about these mid-September days of high pressure and low humidity, bluebird skies where I stay and a kind of promise in the atmosphere that everything’s copacetic: They make me want to cook up some projects, too.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Create New National Parks to Relieve Crowding?
description: Readers express skepticism that it would, as a guest essay suggested, reduce the crowds at the iconic parks. Also: Vaccination mandates; letting children go.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
